title: Suspensions from work for medical reasons

body.content:
$!An employer can suspend an employee from work if their health and safety is in danger - sometimes known as a 'medical suspension' or a 'suspension on maternity grounds'. $!

Employees may be suspended:

+ on medical grounds (eg if they have a serious allergic reaction to a chemical they use at work)
+ if they find out they're pregnant and work in a lab that uses radiation

Employers should do a [risk assessment](http://www.hse.gov.uk/risk/risk-assessment.htm) before suspending an employee. They can offer an employee other suitable work on their normal terms and conditions instead.

##Employees' right to pay if suspended

An employee who's been in their job for a month or more has the right to their normal pay (including bonuses) for up to a maximum of 26 weeks. 

Employers should deduct tax and National Insurance through their [normal payroll procedures](/expenses-and-benefits-medical-suspension-payments).

This isn't the same as [Statutory Sick Pay](/statutory-sick-pay-ssp) and the employee doesn't have to be signed off by a GP.    

^Only employees are eligible for pay when suspended - staff should check their [employment status](/employment-status) to see if they're classed as an 'employee'.^

Staff won't have the right to pay if:

+ they're an independent contractor or agency worker (ie not an 'employee')
+ they refuse other alternative suitable work from their employer without a good reason 
+ they aren't available when their employer needs them to do suitable alternative work

##Pregnant employees

An employer must do a risk assessment of any health and safety dangers to pregnant employees and their babies, and [take reasonable steps to remove them](/working-when-pregnant-your-rights).

If the employer can't remove any risks they should suspend the employee on full pay. The suspension will last as long as the employee or their baby are in danger. 

##Problems with suspension on medical grounds

If an employee has a problem with their employer about anything to do with a suspension for medical or maternity reasons, they should try to solve it informally. 

If the issue can’t be solved, the employee could raise a [grievance](/raise-grievance-at-work).

^Information for employers: get advice on handling [grievances](/handling-employee-grievances).^

An employer can suspend an employee from work if their health and safety is in danger - sometimes known as a ‘medical suspension’ or a ‘suspension on maternity grounds’.

Employees may be suspended:

  • on medical grounds (eg if they have a serious allergic reaction to a chemical they use at work)
  • if they find out they’re pregnant and work in a lab that uses radiation

Employers should do a risk assessment before suspending an employee. They can offer an employee other suitable work on their normal terms and conditions instead.

Employees’ right to pay if suspended

An employee who’s been in their job for a month or more has the right to their normal pay (including bonuses) for up to a maximum of 26 weeks.

Employers should deduct tax and National Insurance through their normal payroll procedures.

This isn’t the same as Statutory Sick Pay and the employee doesn’t have to be signed off by a GP.

Only employees are eligible for pay when suspended - staff should check their employment status to see if they’re classed as an ‘employee’.

Staff won’t have the right to pay if:

  • they’re an independent contractor or agency worker (ie not an ‘employee’)
  • they refuse other alternative suitable work from their employer without a good reason
  • they aren’t available when their employer needs them to do suitable alternative work

Pregnant employees

An employer must do a risk assessment of any health and safety dangers to pregnant employees and their babies, and take reasonable steps to remove them.

If the employer can’t remove any risks they should suspend the employee on full pay. The suspension will last as long as the employee or their baby are in danger.

Problems with suspension on medical grounds

If an employee has a problem with their employer about anything to do with a suspension for medical or maternity reasons, they should try to solve it informally.

If the issue can’t be solved, the employee could raise a grievance.

Information for employers: get advice on handling grievances.
